title: How to Cut Artichokes

methods.name: Cutting Your Artichokes for Boiling or Steaming

steps.headline: Slice off the top third of the artichoke.
steps.description: This will likely be 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) from the top. Lay the artichoke on its side while you do this.

steps.headline: Use kitchen shears to snip off the top portion of the leaves.
steps.description: You do this to remove the thorns. This is optional -- it just lends to a more finished look. It’s also fine to keep the leaves whole.

steps.headline: Cut off the stem.
steps.description: Lay the artichoke on its side to cut it. It’s usually fine to cut about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the bottom of the artichoke. However, if you want the artichoke to be able to sit upright, you can cut closer to the base. Discard the stem once you’ve cut it. Alternatively, if you don’t want to just throw away the stem, you can use a Y-peeler -- a Y-shaped vegetable peeler -- to easily peel away the tough outer skin of the stem to reach the soft, white, edible interior.

steps.headline: Pull off the green outer leaves of the artichoke.
steps.description: Begin with the outermost layer of leaves and work your way up. This will reveal the tender inner leaves. The yellow inner leaves are the ones surrounding the heart.

steps.headline: Take off the yellow inner leaves.
steps.description: They will be more flimsy than the green leaves. Once you’re finished, you should see the pink center of the artichoke. You don’t have to discard the leaves! You can set them aside and cook them separately, eating them by scraping the tender fleshy part off the top with your teeth.

steps.headline: Remove the purple-tipped leaves and their attached spines.
steps.description: These leaves will likely be a bit more stiff, but you can remove them by simply grabbing them at their tops and pulling. Be extra careful, as these inner leaves have sharp spines on the end of them. Remove these spines completely.

steps.headline: Scrape out the choke from the inside of the heart.
steps.description: The choke is the fuzzy part on the inside of the heart that would have eventually bloomed into a flower if the artichoke had not been harvested. You can use a paring knife to do this. It’s similar to carving a pumpkin -- use your utensil to scrape the inside walls of the artichoke, removing the choke entirely. Once you’re finished, you’ll be left with the soft hollowed-out heart. In place of a paring knife, a spoon, melon baller, or cookie dough scoop also work. If you’d like, you can cut the heart in half length-wise to make this process easier. The choke is not edible. Throw it away. It’d probably be super unpleasant to eat.

steps.headline: Remove the stem by laying the artichoke on its side.
steps.description: Cut the stem close to the bottom of the artichoke if you want it to sit flat. This is optional, as the inside of the stem (once you peel away the tough, green outer layer) is edible and flavorful. You can peel off the outer skin using a Y-peeler.

steps.headline: Cut away the harder leaves that form the base of the heart.
steps.description: These are not edible. Trim away any remaining leaf-like bits with a paring knife, always holding the blade away from you.

steps.headline: Snap off the green outermost leaves to reveal the lighter ones underneath.
steps.description: This method is somewhat of a combination of the above two methods.

steps.headline: Use a paring knife to cut off the top half of each leaf.
steps.description: You can slowly turn the artichoke in your hand as you do this. The idea is that you’re leaving the soft, edible part of the leaf intact while removing the hard, thorny part.

steps.headline: Cut off the remaining center leaves.
steps.description: Lie the artichoke on its side to do this. This should leave something that looks somewhat like a closed rosebud.

steps.headline: Cut away all the green parts of the stem.
steps.description: You can do this using your paring knife, holding the artichoke upside-down and moving the blade up along the length of the stem. When you’re done, the edible, white part of the stem will remain. You can also use a Y-peeler, holding the artichoke right-side up and moving the peeler down the length of the stem.
